instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_WLAN: What is PP3V3_WLAN? PP3V3_WLAN is a 3.3v power rail that powers the wifi circuit or wifi card. This can go missing when the inductor acting as a fuse before PP3V3_WLAN blows..
definitions.AP_RESET_L: What is AP_RESET_L? AP_RESET_L resets the wifi hardware when it is low, which will keep it from working. AP_RESET_L needs to be high for reset to not be asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.AP_PWR_EN: What is AP_PWR_EN? AP_PWR_EN is a signal that enables power for the wifi circuit and wifi card. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
I recently bought this 2012 MBP 15" <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b that had the no wifi hardware detected error. 

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> and L3504 but my readings remain similar on all the pieces next to the wifi connector. On <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> I know pin 3 (<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL>) should be reading higher which is why I replaced it from a donor board. 

Could it be <RESISTOR>R3550</RESISTOR>? I'm getting 32.7 Ohm and on diode mode pin 1 is OL and pin 2 is 1.04v.
1. <SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL> - 003v
2. <SIGNAL>PM_WLAN_EN_L</SIGNAL> - .002v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.35v
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL> - 003v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL> - 3.35v
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL> - 003v
<SIGNAL>PM_WLAN_EN_L</SIGNAL> - .002v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN</SIGNAL> - .261v
<SIGNAL>WIFI_EVENT_L</SIGNAL> - .221v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL> - .185

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
"On <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> I know pin 3 (<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL>) should be reading higher"
Who told you that???
You should know first how a MOSFET works; a P-channel in this case.
STOP to make wrong assumptions in the future!

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL> - 3.35v"
Any reason to touch <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR>, if it gives output voltage???

"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL> - .185"
XW3552 is corroded; open trace, didn't check it?

Please, do NOT write the end "V" for diode mode readings in the future.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
Okay. I'm still learning. 
As far as XW3552 that isn't present on the board. However a test pad is. 
TP(1)<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL> XW3552 is reading 3.32
I checked continuity from the test pad to <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> pin 4 and <CAPACITOR>C3550</CAPACITOR> pin 1 is present.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
XW3552 bridge is between <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> and L3504.
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL> - 3.35v
--------
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL> - .185"
Does this look like continuity???
Run a tiny wire there...

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
I ran a jumper from L3504 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL>) to <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL>) and now get 3.35v, but still no wifi hardware showing up in network pref. I do get Bluetooth, so card is connected.

However from pin 3 on <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> I am still getting 0v. I realize you said it's a mosfet but power is not going to other parts. 

L3504
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN</SIGNAL> - 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

At <CAPACITOR>C3550</CAPACITOR>  reading 51.5kOhms
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL>  - 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL> - 0v

<CAPACITOR>C3551</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.32v
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL> - 0v

<RESISTOR>R3550</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_WLAN_EN_L</SIGNAL> - 0v

I have changed different wifi card and flex cables all with similar readings.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
Still concerned with <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> :(.
Why, if already got correct L3504 voltage???

I can only repeat myself...
"You should know first how a MOSFET works; a P-channel in this case."
Google may help you.

Now post all <CHIP>U3540</CHIP> voltages (airport connected).

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
I know how a mosfet works, what my question was is why nothing is passing through.

I turned the board over with airport card connected, attached the magsafe and heard a pop. I do not have 3v or 5v rails.

I have green light. I am going to have to track this down. So this is done for the time being until I find the piece that shorted.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
Okay changed DC-in 

<CHIP>U3540</CHIP> with Airport card connected.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.32v
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_VMON</SIGNAL> - .995v
<SIGNAL>AP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32v
<SIGNAL>AP_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.22v
GND

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R3554</RESISTOR> is jumping around when I do an Ohms reading. 178k to 192k jumping.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL> - 3.32v
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_VMON</SIGNAL> - .995v

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
"I know how a mosfet works, what my question was is why nothing is passing through."
You've said to get correct L3504 voltage; how "nothing is passing through" now?
"I ran a jumper from L3504 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_F</SIGNAL>) to <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN_R</SIGNAL>) and now get 3.35v"

Just to let the things clear:
<SIGNAL>P3V3WLAN_SS</SIGNAL>  must be 0V to get 3V at L3504.
Stop to bother you with <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR>, once you've got that voltage.

"<SIGNAL>AP_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.22v
-------
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_Q_L</SIGNAL>- 3.32v
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32v"
All these bad; did you check with airport card connected?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
Both reading zero with card now connected. Previous without after plugging in different DC-in board.

<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_Q_L</SIGNAL>- 0v
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> - 0v"

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
That's good.
Just to confirm, post again all <CHIP>U3540</CHIP> pins voltage.
Check if L3501 is good.
Also check <RESISTOR>R3510</RESISTOR>/11 and <CAPACITOR>C3530</CAPACITOR>/31.

For the future, do not measure voltages for airport, SSD, or LCD, if corresponding device is not connected.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
Sorry to take your day for this... 

I did find that L3501 had fallen off at one point of the day (it was there earlier). I replaced it and am getting .372v on all four contacts
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_AP_CONN_N</SIGNAL> - .372v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_AP_N</SIGNAL> - .372v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100_AP_P</SIGNAL> - .372v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100_AP_CONN_P</SIGNAL> - .372v

With airport card connected.

<RESISTOR>R3510</RESISTOR> 
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_D2R_R_P</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_D2R_P</SIGNAL> 0v

<RESISTOR>R3511</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_D2R_R_N</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_D2R_N</SIGNAL> - 0v

<CAPACITOR>C3530</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_R2D_N</SIGNAL> - .153v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_R2D_C_N</SIGNAL> - .524v

<CAPACITOR>C3531</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_R2D_P</SIGNAL> - .153v
<SIGNAL>PCIE_AP_R2D_C_P</SIGNAL> - .534v

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
FIXED! I have WIFI!

I guess after the earlier jumper wire installed between L3504 and <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> had worked. It was just that L3501 had been knocked off during my many times moving the board around. 

Thank-you again for your efforts. Thank-you for having patience with a newbie.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mid-2012 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Wifi Hardware detected
threads.message:
No need to check voltage, these are data lines.
Diode mode readings can help.
But I mentioned them just to check if all are there.

For L3501, I was expecting to check its continuity; not voltage, nor even diode mode.
